markdownRemark.html:
I have recently quite enjoyed the use of TODO comments (or TODOs). On one hand there is something really off-putting about having TODOs littered all over your code base. Like threads of thought that did not have time to fully develop and are now dangling appendages of what could have been if only someone had finished the job at time, but for whatever reason could not.

At their worst TODOs are things that I would avoid placing in code. Your collaborators (or your future self) will come across them lacking the context of your train of thought. In this way a TODO comment can really feel like a compromise that was made without a clear rationale and so appear like work uncompleted. Usually a standard comment is more appropriate and should be used liberally in cases where code may be in a state that is hard for new readers to reason about.

At their best TODOs are indicators of future work placed right in the code itself. It could be a brief description of a feature or a simple indicator that standard protocol was skipped for the sake of brevity — in my case writing front-end code may call for the addition of high quality copy that end users will read, but may not be worth spending time on now because this version of your contribution (usually in the form of a PR) is not finalized.

I would like to propose that a TODO can be most effective not when the yet-to-be-built thing is ill-conceived, but rather it is precisely at its most useful when others can read the code, encounter the TODO and exclaim “YES! That would be a great next iteration”.
